content_text_w_o_tags: You can find services by querying SkyDNS via any DNS client or utility. It uses a known domain syntax with subdomains to find matching services.  For the purpose of this document, let's suppose we have added the following services to etcd:    * @abstr_number .rails.production.east.skydns.local, mapping to service @abstr_number .example.com   * @abstr_number .rails.production.west.skydns.local, mapping to service @abstr_number .example.com   * @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local, mapping to @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number   * @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local, mapping to @abstr_number :: @abstr_number : @abstr_number    These names can be added with:       curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/local/skydns/east/production/rails/ @abstr_number  \         -d value='{"host":"service @abstr_number .example.com","port": @abstr_number }'     curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/local/skydns/west/production/rails/ @abstr_number  \         -d value='{"host":"service @abstr_number .example.com","port": @abstr_number }'     curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/local/skydns/east/staging/rails/ @abstr_number  \         -d value='{"host":" @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number ","port": @abstr_number }'     curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/local/skydns/east/staging/rails/ @abstr_number  \         -d value='{"host":" @abstr_number :: @abstr_number : @abstr_number ","port": @abstr_number }'   Testing one of the names with dig:       % dig @localhost SRV  @abstr_number .rails.production.east.skydns.local      ;; ANSWER SECTION:      @abstr_number .rails.production.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number  IN SRV  @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number  service @abstr_number .example.com.
abstracted_heading_plus_content: Service Discovery via the DNS  You can find services by querying SkyDNS via any DNS client or utility. It uses a known domain syntax with subdomains to find matching services.  For the purpose of this document, let's suppose we have added the following services to etcd:    * @abstr_number .rails.production.east.skydns.local, mapping to service @abstr_number .example.com   * @abstr_number .rails.production.west.skydns.local, mapping to service @abstr_number .example.com   * @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local, mapping to @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number   * @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local, mapping to @abstr_number :: @abstr_number : @abstr_number    These names can be added with:       curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/local/skydns/east/production/rails/ @abstr_number  \         -d value='{"host":"service @abstr_number .example.com","port": @abstr_number }'     curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/local/skydns/west/production/rails/ @abstr_number  \         -d value='{"host":"service @abstr_number .example.com","port": @abstr_number }'     curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/local/skydns/east/staging/rails/ @abstr_number  \         -d value='{"host":" @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number ","port": @abstr_number }'     curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/local/skydns/east/staging/rails/ @abstr_number  \         -d value='{"host":" @abstr_number :: @abstr_number : @abstr_number ","port": @abstr_number }'   Testing one of the names with dig:       % dig @localhost SRV  @abstr_number .rails.production.east.skydns.local      ;; ANSWER SECTION:      @abstr_number .rails.production.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number  IN SRV  @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number  service @abstr_number .example.com.

content_text_w_o_tags: Of course using the full names isn't _that_ useful, so SkyDNS lets you query for subdomains, and returns responses based upon the amount of services matched by the subdomain or from the wildcard query.  If we are interested in all the servers in the east region, we simply omit the rightmost labels from our query:       % dig @localhost SRV east.skydns.local      ;; ANSWER SECTION:     east.skydns.local.       @abstr_number     IN      SRV      @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number  service @abstr_number .example.com.     east.skydns.local.       @abstr_number     IN      SRV      @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.     east.skydns.local.       @abstr_number     IN      SRV      @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.      ;; ADDITIONAL SECTION:      @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number  IN A     @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number      @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number  IN AAAA  @abstr_number :: @abstr_number : @abstr_number   Here all three entries of the east are returned.  There is one other feature at play here. The second and third names, { @abstr_number , @abstr_number }.rails.staging.east.skydns.local, only had an IP record configured. Here SkyDNS used the etcd path (also see TargetStrip) to construct a target name and then puts the actual IP address in the additional section. Directly querying for the A records of @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local. of course also works:       % dig @localhost -p  @abstr_number  +noall +answer A  @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.       @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number  IN A     @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number   Another way to leads to the same result it to query for *.east.skydns.local, you even put the wildcard (the * or any) in the middle of a name staging.*.skydns.local or staging.any.skydns.local is a valid query, which returns all name in staging, regardless of the region. Multiple wildcards per name are also permitted.  Note that any is synonymous for a *, as shown above.
abstracted_heading_plus_content: Wildcards  Of course using the full names isn't _that_ useful, so SkyDNS lets you query for subdomains, and returns responses based upon the amount of services matched by the subdomain or from the wildcard query.  If we are interested in all the servers in the east region, we simply omit the rightmost labels from our query:       % dig @localhost SRV east.skydns.local      ;; ANSWER SECTION:     east.skydns.local.       @abstr_number     IN      SRV      @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number  service @abstr_number .example.com.     east.skydns.local.       @abstr_number     IN      SRV      @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.     east.skydns.local.       @abstr_number     IN      SRV      @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.      ;; ADDITIONAL SECTION:      @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number  IN A     @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number      @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number  IN AAAA  @abstr_number :: @abstr_number : @abstr_number   Here all three entries of the east are returned.  There is one other feature at play here. The second and third names, { @abstr_number , @abstr_number }.rails.staging.east.skydns.local, only had an IP record configured. Here SkyDNS used the etcd path (also see TargetStrip) to construct a target name and then puts the actual IP address in the additional section. Directly querying for the A records of @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local. of course also works:       % dig @localhost -p  @abstr_number  +noall +answer A  @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.       @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number  IN A     @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number   Another way to leads to the same result it to query for *.east.skydns.local, you even put the wildcard (the * or any) in the middle of a name staging.*.skydns.local or staging.any.skydns.local is a valid query, which returns all name in staging, regardless of the region. Multiple wildcards per name are also permitted.  Note that any is synonymous for a *, as shown above.

content_text_w_o_tags: Now we can try some of our example DNS lookups:
abstracted_heading_plus_content: Examples  Now we can try some of our example DNS lookups:

content_text_w_o_tags: Get all Services in staging.east:       % dig @localhost staging.east.skydns.local. SRV      ;; ANSWER SECTION:     staging.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number  IN  SRV  @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.     staging.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number  IN  SRV  @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.      ;; ADDITIONAL SECTION:      @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number  IN A     @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number      @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number  IN AAAA  @abstr_number :: @abstr_number : @abstr_number   If you ask for a service who's Host value is an IP address you would (in theory) get back a SRV record such as:       % dig @localhost  @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local SRV      ;; ANSWER SECTION:      @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local  @abstr_number  IN SRV  @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number   Where the target of the SRV is an IP address. This is not how SRV records work. SkyDNS will in this case synthesize a domain name and add the actual IP address to the additional section of the response:       % dig @localhost  @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local SRV      ;; ANSWER SECTION:      @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local  @abstr_number  IN SRV  @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.      ;; ADDITIONAL SECTION:      @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number  IN A     @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number   Which conveys the same information and is legal in the DNS. To have some control on how the target names look you can register a service with TargetStrip set to a non-zero value. Setting TargetStrip to " @abstr_number " strips @abstr_number labels from the generated target name:       ;; ANSWER SECTION:      @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local  @abstr_number  IN SRV  @abstr_number   @abstr_number  staging.east.skydns.local.      ;; ADDITIONAL SECTION:     staging.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number  IN A     @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number   Which removed the @abstr_number .rails from the target name.
abstracted_heading_plus_content: SRV Records  Get all Services in staging.east:       % dig @localhost staging.east.skydns.local. SRV      ;; ANSWER SECTION:     staging.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number  IN  SRV  @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.     staging.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number  IN  SRV  @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.      ;; ADDITIONAL SECTION:      @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number  IN A     @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number      @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number  IN AAAA  @abstr_number :: @abstr_number : @abstr_number   If you ask for a service who's Host value is an IP address you would (in theory) get back a SRV record such as:       % dig @localhost  @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local SRV      ;; ANSWER SECTION:      @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local  @abstr_number  IN SRV  @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number   Where the target of the SRV is an IP address. This is not how SRV records work. SkyDNS will in this case synthesize a domain name and add the actual IP address to the additional section of the response:       % dig @localhost  @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local SRV      ;; ANSWER SECTION:      @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local  @abstr_number  IN SRV  @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.      ;; ADDITIONAL SECTION:      @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number  IN A     @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number   Which conveys the same information and is legal in the DNS. To have some control on how the target names look you can register a service with TargetStrip set to a non-zero value. Setting TargetStrip to " @abstr_number " strips @abstr_number labels from the generated target name:       ;; ANSWER SECTION:      @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local  @abstr_number  IN SRV  @abstr_number   @abstr_number  staging.east.skydns.local.      ;; ADDITIONAL SECTION:     staging.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number  IN A     @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number   Which removed the @abstr_number .rails from the target name.

content_text_w_o_tags: To return A records, simply run a normal DNS query for a service matching the above patterns.  Now do a normal DNS query:       % dig @localhost staging.east.skydns.local. A      ;; ANSWER SECTION:     staging.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number  IN  A    @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number   Now you have a list of all known IP Addresses registered running in staging in the east area.  Because we're returning A records and not SRV records, there are no ports listed, so this is only useful when you're querying for services running on ports known to you in advance.
abstracted_heading_plus_content: A/AAAA Records  To return A records, simply run a normal DNS query for a service matching the above patterns.  Now do a normal DNS query:       % dig @localhost staging.east.skydns.local. A      ;; ANSWER SECTION:     staging.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number  IN  A    @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number   Now you have a list of all known IP Addresses registered running in staging in the east area.  Because we're returning A records and not SRV records, there are no ports listed, so this is only useful when you're querying for services running on ports known to you in advance.

content_text_w_o_tags: If a service is added with "mail": true it is _also_ an MX record, the Priority doubles as the MX's Preference.
abstracted_heading_plus_content: MX Records  If a service is added with "mail": true it is _also_ an MX record, the Priority doubles as the MX's Preference.

content_text_w_o_tags: If for an A or AAAA query the IP address can not be parsed, SkyDNS will try to see if there is a chain of names that will lead to an IP address. The chain can not be longer than @abstr_number . So for instance if the following services have been registered:       curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/local/skydns/east/production/rails/ @abstr_number  \         -d value='{"host":"service @abstr_number .skydns.local","port": @abstr_number }'   and       curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/local/skydns/service @abstr_number  \         -d value='{"host":" @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number ","port": @abstr_number }'   We have created the following CNAME chain: @abstr_number .rails.production.east.skydns.local -> service @abstr_number .skydns.local -> @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number. If you then query for an A or AAAA for @abstr_number .rails.production.east.skydns.local SkyDNS returns:        @abstr_number .rails.production.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number   IN  CNAME   service @abstr_number .skydns.local.     service @abstr_number .skydns.local.                  @abstr_number   IN  A        @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number
abstracted_heading_plus_content: CNAME Records  If for an A or AAAA query the IP address can not be parsed, SkyDNS will try to see if there is a chain of names that will lead to an IP address. The chain can not be longer than @abstr_number . So for instance if the following services have been registered:       curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/local/skydns/east/production/rails/ @abstr_number  \         -d value='{"host":"service @abstr_number .skydns.local","port": @abstr_number }'   and       curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/local/skydns/service @abstr_number  \         -d value='{"host":" @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number ","port": @abstr_number }'   We have created the following CNAME chain: @abstr_number .rails.production.east.skydns.local -> service @abstr_number .skydns.local -> @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number. If you then query for an A or AAAA for @abstr_number .rails.production.east.skydns.local SkyDNS returns:        @abstr_number .rails.production.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number   IN  CNAME   service @abstr_number .skydns.local.     service @abstr_number .skydns.local.                  @abstr_number   IN  A        @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number

content_text_w_o_tags: If the CNAME chains leads to a name that falls outside of the domain (i.e. does not end with skydns.local.), a.k.a. an external name, SkyDNS will attempt to resolve that name using the supplied nameservers. If this succeeds the reply is concatenated to the current one and send to the client. So if we register this service:       curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/local/skydns/east/production/rails/ @abstr_number  \         -d value='{"host":"www.miek.nl","port": @abstr_number }'   Doing an A/AAAA query for this will lead to the following response:        @abstr_number .rails.production.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number  IN CNAME www.miek.nl.     www.miek.nl.             @abstr_number     IN      CNAME   a.miek.nl.     a.miek.nl.               @abstr_number     IN      A        @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number   The first CNAME is generated from within SkyDNS, the other CNANE is returned from the remote name server.
abstracted_heading_plus_content: External Names  If the CNAME chains leads to a name that falls outside of the domain (i.e. does not end with skydns.local.), a.k.a. an external name, SkyDNS will attempt to resolve that name using the supplied nameservers. If this succeeds the reply is concatenated to the current one and send to the client. So if we register this service:       curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/local/skydns/east/production/rails/ @abstr_number  \         -d value='{"host":"www.miek.nl","port": @abstr_number }'   Doing an A/AAAA query for this will lead to the following response:        @abstr_number .rails.production.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number  IN CNAME www.miek.nl.     www.miek.nl.             @abstr_number     IN      CNAME   a.miek.nl.     a.miek.nl.               @abstr_number     IN      A        @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number   The first CNAME is generated from within SkyDNS, the other CNANE is returned from the remote name server.

content_text_w_o_tags: SkyDNS also allows you to query for TXT records. Just register a json with the 'text' field set.
abstracted_heading_plus_content: TXT Records  SkyDNS also allows you to query for TXT records. Just register a json with the 'text' field set.

content_text_w_o_tags: For DNS to work properly SkyDNS needs to tell its parents its nameservers. This information is stored inside etcd, under the key local/skydns/dns/ns. There multiple services maybe stored. Note these services MUST use IP address, using names will not work. For instance:       curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/local/skydns/dns/ns/ns @abstr_number  \         -d value='{"host":" @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number "}'   Registers ns @abstr_number .ns.dns.skydns.local as a nameserver with IP address @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number :       % dig @localhost NS skydns.local      ;; ANSWER SECTION:     skydns.local.        @abstr_number     IN  NS  ns @abstr_number .ns.dns.skydns.local.      ;; ADDITIONAL SECTION:     n @abstr_number .ns.dns.skydns.local.     @abstr_number     IN  A    @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number   Having the nameserver(s) in etcd make sense because usually it is hard for SkyDNS to figure this out by itself, especially when running behind NAT or running on @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number and being forwarded packets IPv @abstr_number packets, etc. etc.
abstracted_heading_plus_content: NS Records  For DNS to work properly SkyDNS needs to tell its parents its nameservers. This information is stored inside etcd, under the key local/skydns/dns/ns. There multiple services maybe stored. Note these services MUST use IP address, using names will not work. For instance:       curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/local/skydns/dns/ns/ns @abstr_number  \         -d value='{"host":" @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number "}'   Registers ns @abstr_number .ns.dns.skydns.local as a nameserver with IP address @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number :       % dig @localhost NS skydns.local      ;; ANSWER SECTION:     skydns.local.        @abstr_number     IN  NS  ns @abstr_number .ns.dns.skydns.local.      ;; ADDITIONAL SECTION:     n @abstr_number .ns.dns.skydns.local.     @abstr_number     IN  A    @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number   Having the nameserver(s) in etcd make sense because usually it is hard for SkyDNS to figure this out by itself, especially when running behind NAT or running on @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number and being forwarded packets IPv @abstr_number packets, etc. etc.

content_text_w_o_tags: When registering a service with an IP address only, you might also want to register the reverse (adding a hostname the address points to). In the DNS these records are called PTR records.  So looking back at some of the services in the section "Service Discovery via the DNS", we register these IP only ones:        @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number   To add the reverse of this address you need to add the DNS name that will be used when doing a reverse lookup. With dig -x <IP address> you can easiliy find what the reverse name should be:       % dig -x  @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number  +noall +question     ; @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number .in-addr.arpa.   IN  PTR   So the name must be @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number .in-addr.arpa which should point to @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.  These can be added with the following command. Note that the IP address is reversed _again_ and is actually back in its original form.       curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/arpa/in-addr/ @abstr_number / @abstr_number / @abstr_number / @abstr_number  \         -d value='{"host":" @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local"}'   If SkyDNS receives a PTR query it will check these paths and will return the contents. Note that these replies are sent with the AA (Authoritative Answer) bit _off_. If nothing is found locally the query is forwarded to the local recursor (if so configured), otherwise SERVFAIL is returned.  This also works for IPv @abstr_number addresses, except that the reverse path is quite long.
abstracted_heading_plus_content: PTR Records: Reverse Addresses  When registering a service with an IP address only, you might also want to register the reverse (adding a hostname the address points to). In the DNS these records are called PTR records.  So looking back at some of the services in the section "Service Discovery via the DNS", we register these IP only ones:        @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.  @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number   To add the reverse of this address you need to add the DNS name that will be used when doing a reverse lookup. With dig -x <IP address> you can easiliy find what the reverse name should be:       % dig -x  @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number  +noall +question     ; @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number .in-addr.arpa.   IN  PTR   So the name must be @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number .in-addr.arpa which should point to @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local.  These can be added with the following command. Note that the IP address is reversed _again_ and is actually back in its original form.       curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/arpa/in-addr/ @abstr_number / @abstr_number / @abstr_number / @abstr_number  \         -d value='{"host":" @abstr_number .rails.staging.east.skydns.local"}'   If SkyDNS receives a PTR query it will check these paths and will return the contents. Note that these replies are sent with the AA (Authoritative Answer) bit _off_. If nothing is found locally the query is forwarded to the local recursor (if so configured), otherwise SERVFAIL is returned.  This also works for IPv @abstr_number addresses, except that the reverse path is quite long.

content_text_w_o_tags: By specifying nameservers in SkyDNS's config, for instance @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number , @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number, you create a DNS forwarding proxy. In this case it round-robins between the two nameserver IPs mentioned.  Requests for which SkyDNS isn't authoritative will be forwarded and proxied back to the client. This means that you can set SkyDNS as the primary DNS server in /etc/resolv.conf and use it for both service discovery and normal DNS operations.
abstracted_heading_plus_content: DNS Forwarding  By specifying nameservers in SkyDNS's config, for instance @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number , @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number, you create a DNS forwarding proxy. In this case it round-robins between the two nameserver IPs mentioned.  Requests for which SkyDNS isn't authoritative will be forwarded and proxied back to the client. This means that you can set SkyDNS as the primary DNS server in /etc/resolv.conf and use it for both service discovery and normal DNS operations.

content_text_w_o_tags: SkyDNS supports signing DNS answers, also known as DNSSEC. To use it, you need to create a DNSSEC keypair and use that in SkyDNS. For instance, if the domain for SkyDNS is skydns.local:       % dnssec-keygen skydns.local     Generating key pair............++++++ ...................................++++++     Kskydns.local.+ @abstr_number + @abstr_number   This creates two files with the basename Kskydns.local.+ @abstr_number . @abstr_number, one with the extension .key (this holds the public key) and one with the extension .private which holds the private key. The basename of these files should be given to SkyDNS's DNSSEC configuration option like so (together with some other options):       curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/config -d \         value='{"dns_addr":" @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number ","dnssec":"Kskydns.local.+ @abstr_number + @abstr_number "}'   If you then query with dig +dnssec you will get signatures, keys and NSEC @abstr_number records returned. Authenticated denial of existence is implemented using NSEC @abstr_number white lies, see @abstr_hyperlink , Appendix B.

content_text_w_o_tags: SkyDNS supports storing values which are specific for that _instance_ of SkyDNS.  This can be useful when you have SkyDNS running on multiple hosts, but want to store values that are specific for a single host. For example the public IP-address of the host or the IP-address on the tenant network.  To do that you need to specify a unique value for that host with -local. A good unique value for that would be an UUID which you can generate with uuidgen for instance.  That unique value is used as a path in etcd to store the values separately from the normal values. It is still stored in the etcd backend so a restart of SkyDNS with the same unique value will give it access to the old data.  In the example here, we don't use an UUID, we use public.addresses:       % skydns -local public.addresses.skydns.local &      % curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/local/skydns/local/addresses/public \         -d value='{"host":" @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number "}'      % dig @ @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number  local.dns.skydns.local. A      ;; ANSWER SECTION:     local.dns.skydns.local.  @abstr_number  IN  A    @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number   The name local.dns.skydns.local. is fixed, i.e. you can retrieve the Host Local Value by querying for local.dns.<your domain>.

content_text_w_o_tags: Groups can be used to group set of services together. The main use of this is to limit recursion, i.e. don't give back _all_ records, but only a subset. Say that I have configuration like this:       /skydns/local/domain/     /skydns/local/domain/a - {"host": " @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number ", "group": "g @abstr_number "}     /skydns/local/domain/b - {"host": " @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number ", "group": "g @abstr_number "}     /skydns/local/domain/subdom/     /skydns/local/domain/subdom/c - {"host": " @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number ", "group": "g @abstr_number "}     /skydns/local/domain/subdom/d - {"host": " @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number ", "group": "g @abstr_number "}   And you want domain.local to return ( @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number and @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number ) and subdom.domain.local to return ( @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number and @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number ). For this the two domains, need to be in different groups. What those groups are does not matter, as long as a and b belong to the same group which is _different_ from the group c and d belong to. If a service is found _without_ a group it is _always included_.

content_text_w_o_tags: The SkyDNS server package may be used as a library, which allows a custom record retrieval implementation (referred to as a Backend) to be provided. The default Etcd implementation resides under backends/etcd/etcd.go. To provide your own backend implementation, you must implement the server.Backend interface.  If you want to preserve the ability to answer arbitrary queries from etcd, but use your custom implementation for certain subsets of the namespace, the server.FirstBackend helper type will allow you to chain multiple Backends in order. The first backend that answers a Records or ReverseRecord call with a record and with no error will be served.
abstracted_heading_plus_content: Implementing a custom DNS backend  The SkyDNS server package may be used as a library, which allows a custom record retrieval implementation (referred to as a Backend) to be provided. The default Etcd implementation resides under backends/etcd/etcd.go. To provide your own backend implementation, you must implement the server.Backend interface.  If you want to preserve the ability to answer arbitrary queries from etcd, but use your custom implementation for certain subsets of the namespace, the server.FirstBackend helper type will allow you to chain multiple Backends in order. The first backend that answers a Records or ReverseRecord call with a record and with no error will be served.

content_text_w_o_tags: Stub Zones are pointers that point to _another set_ of servers which should provide an answer for the current query. This is similar to the (recursive) forwarding SkyDNS does, but different in that you need to specify a domain name and a set of authoritative servers. Also this can be dynamically controlled by writing values into Etcd. Note, that when enabled SkyDNS will _first_ consult the stub configuration, potentially bypassing any configured local records.  The stub zone configuration lives under stub.dns.skydns.local.. The following example shows on how to set this up. Suppose we want to create a stub zone for skydns.com and point to the nameservers reachable by following address _and_ (optional) ports:    * @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number , port @abstr_number   * @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number , port @abstr_number ( @abstr_number is the default that will be used if there isn't one specified)    We should then register @abstr_number services under the name skydns.com.stub.dns.skydns.local       % curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/local/skydns/dns/stub/com/skydns/ns @abstr_number  \         -d value='{"host":" @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number ", "port": @abstr_number }'     % curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/local/skydns/dns/stub/com/skydns/ns @abstr_number  \         -d value='{"host":" @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number "}'   So the _leaves_ should have the nameserver information.       xxx..stub.dns.skydns.local     |           |     v           |     nameservers |                 v           stub domain name   When SkyDNS receives a query for skydns.com it will _not_ forward it to the recursors, but instead will query @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number on port @abstr_number and if that fails will query @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number (on @abstr_number ) to get an answer. That answer will then be given back to the original client.  When forwarding to a stub, SkyDNS adds a EDNS @abstr_number meta data RR to the packet telling the remote server (if its a SkyDNS instance) that this is a stub request. SkyDNS will not (stub)forward packets with this EDNS @abstr_number meta data, instead the request will be dropped and logged.  Remember this will only work when SkyDNS is started with -stubzones.

heading_text: How Do I Create an Address Pool and Round Robin Between Them
content_text_w_o_tags: You have @abstr_number machines with @abstr_number different IP addresses and you want to have @abstr_number name pointing to all @abstr_number possible addresses. The name we want to use is: db.skydns.local and the @abstr_number addresses are @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number .{ @abstr_number , @abstr_number , @abstr_number }. For this to work we create the hosts named x{ @abstr_number , @abstr_number , @abstr_number }.db.skydns.local in etcd:       curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/local/skydns/db/x @abstr_number  -d \         value='{"host":" @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number "}'     curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/local/skydns/db/x @abstr_number  -d \         value='{"host": " @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number "'}     curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/local/skydns/db/x @abstr_number  -d \         value='{"host": " @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number "'}   Now the name db.skydns.local is the "load balanced" name for the database, SkyDNS will round-robin by default in this case unless -round-robin=false is enabled.

content_text_w_o_tags: You want this response from SkyDNS, which says there are @abstr_number open ports on bar.skydns.local and this name has IP addres @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number :       ;; ANSWER SECTION:     bar.skydns.local.    @abstr_number     IN  SRV  @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number  bar.skydns.local.     bar.skydns.local.    @abstr_number     IN  SRV  @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number  bar.skydns.local.      ;; ADDITIONAL SECTION:     bar.skydns.local.  @abstr_number     IN  A    @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number   So you register a "dummy" host named x @abstr_number:       curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/local/skydns/bar/x @abstr_number  -d \         value='{"host":" @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number ","port": @abstr_number }'     curl -XPUT http:// @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number : @abstr_number /v @abstr_number /keys/skydns/local/skydns/bar/x @abstr_number  -d \         value='{"host": "bar.skydns.local","port": @abstr_number }'   And try it out:       ;; ANSWER SECTION:     bar.skydns.local.    @abstr_number     IN  SRV  @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number  x @abstr_number .bar.skydns.local.     bar.skydns.local.    @abstr_number     IN  SRV  @abstr_number   @abstr_number   @abstr_number  bar.skydns.local.      ;; ADDITIONAL SECTION:     x @abstr_number .bar.skydns.local.  @abstr_number     IN  A    @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number . @abstr_number   Which has x @abstr_number in the name, which is not the name you wanted to see there, and worse does not match the name in the other SRV record. content_text_w_o_tags: Official Docker images are at the @abstr_hyperlink :    * master -> skynetservices/skydns:latest   * latest tag -> skynetservices/skydns:latest-tagged    The supplied Dockerfile can be used to build an image as well. Note that the image is based of Alpine Linux which used musl libc instead of glibc, so when building SkyDNS you must make sure if does not need glibc when run:  Build SkyDNS with:       % GOOS=linux go build -a -tags netgo -installsuffix netgo   And then build the docker image:       % docker build -t $USER/skydns .   If you run it, SkyDNS needs to access Etcd (or whatever backend), which usually runs on the host server (i.e. when using CoreOS), to make that work, just run:       docker run --net host
abstracted_heading_plus_content: Docker  Official Docker images are at the @abstr_hyperlink :    * master -> skynetservices/skydns:latest   * latest tag -> skynetservices/skydns:latest-tagged    The supplied Dockerfile can be used to build an image as well. Note that the image is based of Alpine Linux which used musl libc instead of glibc, so when building SkyDNS you must make sure if does not need glibc when run:  Build SkyDNS with:       % GOOS=linux go build -a -tags netgo -installsuffix netgo   And then build the docker image:       % docker build -t $USER/skydns .   If you run it, SkyDNS needs to access Etcd (or whatever backend), which usually runs on the host server (i.e. when using CoreOS), to make that work, just run:       docker run --net host

abstracted_heading_plus_content: ngplusOverlay Directive  @abstr_image  The ngplusOverlay directive intercepts $http and jQuery XHR calls and displays and overlay. To get started using it follows these steps:  @abstr_number . Add the directive script located in scripts/ngplus-overlay.js into your project and reference the ngplus module: @abstr_number . Reference the ngplus module:  @abstr_code_section  @abstr_number . Add the following styles into a CSS stylesheet (tweak as needed):  @abstr_code_section  @abstr_number . Add the directive into your main shell page:  @abstr_code_section  Once you have the code locally, install @abstr_hyperlink , open a command-prompt and run:  @abstr_code_section  ngplusOverlay directive in action.  Note: This directive was created for a prototype project and has only been tested with Chrome and IE @abstr_number +. It's intended to provide a starting point, evolve over time (please contribute!), and hopefully save someone some time.

content_text_w_o_tags: ngplus-overlay-delay-in=" @abstr_number " indicates the number of milliseconds to wait before showing the overlay. This is useful so we do not have a flicker for super short XHR. Default is @abstr_number ms.   * ngplus-overlay-delay-out=" @abstr_number " indicates the number of milliseconds to keep the overlay around after the last XHR has completed. Default is @abstr_number ms.   * ngplus-overlay-animation="dissolve-animation" indicates the CSS animation to apply. Must be an animation that supports the AngularJS standard for ngShow/ngHide. This is an optional setting.
abstracted_heading_plus_content: Options   ngplus-overlay-delay-in=" @abstr_number " indicates the number of milliseconds to wait before showing the overlay. This is useful so we do not have a flicker for super short XHR. Default is @abstr_number ms.   * ngplus-overlay-delay-out=" @abstr_number " indicates the number of milliseconds to keep the overlay around after the last XHR has completed. Default is @abstr_number ms.   * ngplus-overlay-animation="dissolve-animation" indicates the CSS animation to apply. Must be an animation that supports the AngularJS standard for ngShow/ngHide. This is an optional setting.
